model_solution:
To compute the product of two matrices, we multiply each element in the rows of the first matrix with the corresponding elements in the columns of the second matrix.

So, the first step is to multiply the elements of the first row of the first matrix with the elements of the first column of the second matrix:

(2)(8) + (0)(1) = 16 + 0 = 16

The result of this multiplication is the first element of the resulting matrix. 

Next, multiply the elements of the first row of the first matrix with the elements of the second column of the second matrix: 
(2)(-2) + (0)(1) = -4 + 0 = -4 

The result is the second element of the first row in the resulting matrix.
To find the elements in the second row of the resulting matrix, multiply the elements of the second row of the first matrix with the elements of the first column of the second matrix: 
(5)(8) + (-3)(1) = 40 - 3 = 37

Next, multiply the elements of the second row of the first matrix with the elements of the second column of the second matrix: 
(5)(-2) + (-3)(1) = -10 - 3 = -13
To complete the multiplication, the resulting matrix will be:
$\begin{pmatrix} 16 & -4 \\ 37 & -13 \end{pmatrix}$
To confirm the solution, the resulting matrix is indeed the product of the two given matrices. Therefore, the solution is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 16 & -4 \\ 37 & -13 \end{pmatrix}}$.

full_steps:
To compute the product of two matrices, we multiply each element in the rows of the first matrix with the corresponding elements in the columns of the second matrix.

So, the first step is to multiply the elements of the first row of the first matrix with the elements of the first column of the second matrix:

(2)(8) + (0)(1) = 16 + 0 = 16

The result of this multiplication is the first element of the resulting matrix. 

Next, multiply the elements of the first row of the first matrix with the elements of the second column of the second matrix: 
(2)(-2) + (0)(1) = -4 + 0 = -4 

The result is the second element of the first row in the resulting matrix.

To find the elements in the second row of the resulting matrix, multiply the elements of the second row of the first matrix with the elements of the first column of the second matrix: 
(5)(8) + (-3)(1) = 40 - 3 = 37

Next, multiply the elements of the second row of the first matrix with the elements of the second column of the second matrix: 
(5)(-2) + (-3)(1) = -10 - 3 = -13

To complete the multiplication, the resulting matrix will be:
$\begin{pmatrix} 16 & -4 \\ 37 & -13 \end{pmatrix}$
To confirm the solution, the resulting matrix is indeed the product of the two given matrices. Therefore, the solution is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 16 & -4 \\ 37 & -13 \end{pmatrix}}$.
